id_plant_info.Description: Caladiums are tropical plants with heart-shaped simple alternate leaves ranging in size from 6 to 12 inches. The numerous cultivars offer foliage colors in red, salmon, rose, white, or green with many variegated combinations. Their flower is a spadix surrounded by a yellow-green spathe.  Caladiums prefer a rich soil and shade. Grown mostly for their interesting foliage display, caladiums perform well in garden borders and containers. Fertilize them once a month with 8-8-8 (2 lbs/100 ft2 ). Caladiums do not overwinter in N.C. Therefore, their tubers must be dug in the fall and stored dry at 70 to 75 F. The tubers are replanted in the spring after the last chance of frost. One additional note: most cultivars are adapted to full shade, but many selections tolerate partial sun or early morning sunlight. Full sun generally reduces the intensity of the foliage color of most cultivars.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning and swelling of lips, mouth, tongue; also nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur; contact with cell sap can cause skin irritation
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals and unidentified compounds

id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen vines with stems green and striped with white or yellow; leaves heart-shaped, variegated; flowers in a spadix surrounded by a spathe
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning and swelling of lips, mouth, tongue, and throat, also diarrhea. Skin irritation from frequent contact
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Eucalyptus, gum, lemon scented gum, silver dollar tree
id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen trees with alternate or opposite, simple, smooth-margined leaves; flowers in small clusters, top- or bell-shaped, 4-petaled with many stamens; fruit a many-seeded capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, coma. Skin redness, irritation, and burning from handling leaves and bark. Eucalyptus oil is extremely toxic if eaten
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Eucalyptus, gum, lemon scented gum, silver dollar tree
id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen trees with alternate or opposite, simple, smooth-margined leaves; flowers in small clusters, top- or bell-shaped, 4-petaled with many stamens; fruit a many-seeded capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, coma. Skin redness, irritation, and burning from handling leaves and bark. Eucalyptus oil is extremely toxic if eaten
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub or tree with alternate, simple leaves which are leathery, veiny, and toothed; flowers small, white to whitish-pink, 5-parted; fruit fleshy, yellow
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Weakness, vomiting, labored breathing, twitching, stupor, convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Burning bush, hearts-a-bustin', spindle tree, strawberry bush, wahoo
id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous or evergreen shrub with leaves opposite and simple; flowers small, 4-parted, greenish maroon; fruit a reddish, pink, ivory to yellow capsule splitting and showing orange-red seeds
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, chills, coma, and convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: A woody, branched, very spiny shrub with milky latex; leaves few, smooth-margined; the cup-shaped "flowers" located just above 2, broad, scarlet bracts
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea when ingested; redness, swelling, blisters after some delay following contact with skin
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES. CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous or evergreen shrub with leaves opposite and simple; flowers small, 4-parted, greenish maroon; fruit a reddish, pink, ivory to yellow capsule splitting and showing orange-red seeds
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, chills, coma, and convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb with opposite, toothed leaves; flowers white, in terminal, rounded clusters
id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Ingestion of raw milk from cows feeding on the plant
id_plant_info.Symptoms: "Milk sickness": weakness, nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, delirium, prostration, coma
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Slender, diffusely branched herb with milky cell sap; leaves alternate below and opposite above, simple, smooth-margined; conspicuous white, petal-like appendages on the rim of the cup-shaped "flower."
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea when ingested; redness, swelling, blisters after some delay following contact with skin
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb with erect stems; leaves narrow and very crowded above; yellow, crescent-shaped glands on the rim of the cup-shaped "flower."
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea when ingested; redness, swelling, blisters after some delay following contact with skin
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea when ingested; redness, swelling, blisters after some delay following contact with skin
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual herb with milky latex, the leaves alternate or whorled above, smooth on the margin, the upper leaves white on the margin; the petal-like appendages on the rim of the cup-shaped "flower" white
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea when ingested; redness, swelling, blisters after some delay following contact with skin
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, toothed with 1 tooth for each secondary vein; flowers small and inconspicuous; fruit a 3-angled nut inside of a weakly spiny husk.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach upset.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Carolina jasmine, Carolina jessamine, Yellow jessamine
id_plant_info.Description: Woody vine, trailing or high climbing, evergreen; leaves opposite, simple, the margin smooth; flowers yellow, highly aromatic, funnel-shaped with 5 lobes; fruit a thin, flattened capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Sweating, nausea, muscular weakness, dilated pupils, lowered temperature, convulsions, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial, diffusely branched herb with opposite leaves; flowers many, small, white or pink, 5-parted, sometimes double-flowered
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Eyes, nose, and sinus irritation and asthma after repeated handling; skin irritation after contact
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Grevillea 'Robyn Gordon', Silky oak, silver oak
id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen trees and shrubs; leaves alternate, deeply lobed or toothed; flowers in a terminal cluster, tubular, white, red, yellow, or orange.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Intense itching, streaking, and blisters, often delayed after contact.
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Description: Woody, evergreen, climbing or creeping vine; leaves alternate, simple, the juvenile form palmately 3-5-lobed, usually lacking hairs, often variegated; flowers small, greenish yellow, 5-parted; fruit fleshy, black
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Severe skin irritation with redness, itching, and blisters following contact with cell sap; burning sensation of throat after eating berries; delirium, stupor, convulsions, hallucinations, fever, and rash following ingestion of leaves
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Description: Annual and perennial herbs; leaves alternate, simple, glandular-dotted; flowers yellow, in convex heads with ray flowers.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, elevated temperature and pulse, difficulty of breathing, vomiting, and convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous shrub; leaves opposite, simple, stalked, toothed and sometimes lobed; flowers in terminal, round or umbrella-shaped clusters and nearly always white or cream colored. Several named cultivars have sterile flowers making a ball-shaped bloom. A few modern hybrids have been bred to have pink flowers. Unique to H. arborescens, the flower color is not affected by the soil pH. Hydrangea arborescens is very cold hardy but will also grow in warmer Carolina climates.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, stomach pain, vomiting, sweating.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Erect, evergreen, unbranched, perennial herb; leaves alternate, palmately divided with 7-9 leaflets; flowers solitary or 2-3, 5-parted, white becoming pink or purplish.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning of mouth and throat, salivation, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, nervous symptoms, depression. Skin irritation after contact with cell sap.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous shrubs; leaves opposite, simple, stalked, toothed and sometimes lobed; flowers in terminal, round or conical-shaped clusters, primarily white or slightly pink, at times 8 to 10 inches in length; the sterile flowers (around the margin or the entire cluster) are much enlarged. Can be grown as a tree. Very coarse - difficult to use in most designs.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, stomach pain, vomiting, sweating.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial, herbaceous, twining vine; leaves mostly opposite, palmately 3-7-veined and -lobed; flowers small, axillary, 5-parted; fruits in an elongated cluster, each small, dry, enclosed in a sac-like, papery bract.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Skin irritation with blisters upon contact
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES

id_plant_info.Description: Bulbous herbs with basal, strap-shaped leaves; flowering stem stout and hollow bearing 2-many stalked flowers at the top, each horizontal or drooping, funnel-shaped, 6-parted, of various colors.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, possibly diarrhea
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, fan-shaped; seeds (only on female trees) plumlike, yellow-orange, the outer, fleshy pulp foul-smelling when ripe, the inner wall hard, smooth, and cream colored
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Fleshy, outer pulp of the seeds, and raw seed kernel
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Irritation of the skin following contact with juice of the seed pulp; irritation of lips, mouth, and throat and stomach pain, nausea, and diarrhea after eating pulp
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: An alkyl phenol and ginkgolic acid
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Climbing lily, Flame lily, Glory lily
id_plant_info.Description: Slender, herbaceous vine from a thick tuberous rootstock; leaves alternate or appearing opposite, simple, strap-like with a tendril-like tip; flowers on long stalks, 6-parted, yellow or red with wavy margins
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: All parts, especially tubers (thickened roots) which resemble yams
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Numbness of lips, tongue, and throat, thirst, fever, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, difficult breathing, convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Small, evergreen shrub; leaves simple, opposite or in whorls of 3; flowers pinkish, in short lateral clusters, each saucer-shaped with 5 shallow lobes, the 10 anthers at first stuck in small pockets; fruit a capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, slow pulse, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, tingling of skin, lack of coordination, convulsions, paralysis
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Andromedotoxin, a resinoid; arbutin, a glycoside
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree with opposite, palmately divided leaves with 5 leaflets; flowers with 5 white petals in large, terminal clusters; fruit is a prickly, leathery capsule with large, shiny, brown seeds, each with a pale scar
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Seeds and tea made from leaves and sprouts
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Muscle weakness and paralysis, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, depression, paralysis, and stupor
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Glycoside aesculin, saponin aescin, possibly alkaloids

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous shrubs; leaves opposite, simple, stalked, toothed and sometimes lobed; flowers in terminal, round or umbrella-shaped clusters, white, pink, or blue, 4- 5-parted, the sterile flowers (around the margin or the entire cluster) are much enlarged.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, stomach pain, vomiting, sweating.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Erect, perennial herb with conspicuous stinging hairs throughout; leaves alternate, simple, coarsely toothed; flowers small and inconspicuous, in axillary clusters
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Intense burning and itching or stinging lasting usually less than an hour
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Mixture of chemicals, not well understood
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES

id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Glycosides: syringin (ligustrin), a glycoside; shikimic acid (lowest toxic dose 4,000mg); and others
id_plant_info.Severity: Treat with caution

id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Headache, abdominal pain, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation

id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous shrubs; leaves simple and alternate; flowers small, white or pink, urn-shaped and drooping, in terminal clusters; fruit a globose or pear-shaped capsule, not depressed at the apex.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, slow pulse, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, tingling of skin, lack of coordination, convulsions, paralysis
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Caution: not known to be poisonous but related to known toxic plants.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Matrimony vine, box thorn, false jessamine, wolfberry
id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous or evergreen shrubs with spiny stems; leaves alternate, simple, smooth margined; flowers small, 5-parted, funnel-shaped or bell-shaped, white, lilac, purple; fruit a berry, red to purple or yellow
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, abdominal pain, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Description: A bushy herb or shrub with elongated tubers; leaves alternate, simple, deeply lobed; flowers inconspicuous; fruit a 6-angled globose capsule
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Raw roots or peelings of the tubers (thickened roots)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Weak and irregular breathing, weakness, excitement, depression, staggering, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma of short duration
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Woody, deciduous, twining vine without tendrils; leaves alternate, simple, long-stalked, palmately lobed with shallow, rounded lobes; flowers greenish white in small, axillary clusters; fruit a drupe, blue or bluish black, appearing in grapelike clusters, but each with a single seed
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Convulsions; may be fatal
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, 2-pinnately divided with toothed, pointed leaflets; flowers small but numerous in large terminal clusters, lilac-colored; fruit a yellowish, wrinkled drupe persisting through the winter
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach irritation, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, paralysis, irregular breathing, and respiratory distress
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Tetranortriterpene neurotoxins; also possibly a saponin
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual, biennial, or perennial herbs; leaves alternate, simple or palmately divided; flowers showy in terminal, elongated clusters, pea-like, blue to purple, pinkish or white; fruit an elongated, flattened pod.

id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Alkaloids such as lupinine, anagyrine, sparteine, and hydroxylupanine

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Dog hobble, Drooping leucothoe, Fetter bush, fetterbush
id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub with green and broadly arching stems; leaves alternate, simple, taper-pointed; flowers on all sides of elongated, axillary clusters, each white, inverted urn-shaped with 5 small lobes; fruit a globular, 5-lobed capsule more or less depressed at the apex.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation and nasal discharge, sweating, tingling sensation, headache, depression, weakness, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, paralysis
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Erect, much branched herb; leaves opposite, simple; flowers opening late in the afternoon or in very cloudy weather, white to red, yellow or striped, tubular and trumpet-like, 5-lobed; fruit leathery, 5-ribbed
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; handling of the roots may cause dermatitis
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual, climbing vine; leaves alternate, foul-smelling, deeply palmately lobed; flowers yellow, tubular; fruit a berry, yellow-orange, warty, with red pulp around seeds
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Outer fruit coat, seeds, ripe fruit
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, salivation, facial redness, pupil dilation, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscular weakness
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Small, deciduous tree; leaves alternate, long-stalked with 3 leaflets; flowers pea-like, golden, in long drooping clusters; fruit a long, flattened pod
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nervousness, stomach and intestinal irritation with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; irregular pulse, convulsions, coma; may be fatal
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Woody vine; leaves alternate, simple, large, leathery, conspicuously lobed and with elongated holes throughout the blade; flowers small on a spadix and surrounded by a greenish or whitish spathe; fruit fleshy and pineapple-like
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Intense burning of mouth, tongue, and throat; nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may also occur; contact with cell sap may cause skin irritation
id_plant_info.Symptoms: EDIBLE PARTS: Ripe fruit, but some people are allergic
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Needle-like calcium oxalate crystals; possibly other unidentified toxins
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous trees with alternate, simple, toothed leaves, either unlobed, mitten-shaped, or 3-lobed, usually smooth above and hairless below; flowers small in a tight cluster; fruit white, pink, or purplish, clustered like a blackberry
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Unripe fruit and milky sap from all parts
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Hallucinations and stomach upset
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial, bulbous herbs; leaves narrow, flat, and strap-like; flowers single or in a cluster at the top of a naked stem, each white to yellow or red, with a tubular projection above the 6 spreading petal-like parts; fruit a capsule.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, salivation, trembling, convulsions; may be fatal. Contact dermatitis ("lily rash") following handling of bulbs, flowers, and stems.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Phenanthridine alkaloids such as lycorine, also calcium oxalate crystals.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Rabbit ears cactus, prickly pear cactus
id_plant_info.Description: Succulent, flattened stems or shrublike with cylindric stems; leaves lacking or modified into large spines; sharp-pointed glochids in clusters at base of spines; flowers variously colored, with many petals; fruit fleshy or dry.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Glochids (minute bristle-like, barbed hairs in clusters) on the stems (green, thickened stems resemble leaves).
id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Ingestion; splinter-like small infection due to glochids lodged in the skin, eye irritation.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Painful skin and eye irritation following contact; internal effects in diabetics from ingestion.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Unknown; possibly mechanical effect of glochids.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, slow pulse, dizziness, collapse, and respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Succulent, flattened stems or shrublike with cylindric stems; leaves lacking or modified into large spines; sharp-pointed glochids in clusters at base of spines; flowers variously colored, with many petals; fruit fleshy or dry.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Glochids (minute bristle-like, barbed hairs in clusters) on the stems (green, thickened stems resemble leaves).
id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Ingestion; splinter-like small infection due to glochids lodged in the skin, eye irritation.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Painful skin and eye irritation following contact; internal effects in diabetics from ingestion.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Unknown; possibly mechanical effect of glochids.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Description: Shrub or small tree; leaves alternate, simple, white-waxy; flowers tubular, cream or yellow-green, 5-lobed at top; fruit a capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, slow pulse, dizziness, collapse, and respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Herbaceous perennial from a bulb; leaves basal, narrow, strap-like, with a light green midrib; flowers in a cluster at the top of a naked stem, white to pale yellow, star-like, 6-parted, in O. umbellatum the parts with a green stripe on the back
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, salivation, vomiting, diarrhea, shortness of breath; pain, burning, and swelling of lips, tongue, and throat. Skin irritation following prolonged contact

id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual or perennial herbs; leaves long-stalked with 3 leaflets; flowers 5-parted, white, yellow, lavender, or rose; fruit a capsule.

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Caution: large quantities may cause trembling, cramps, and staggering as in grazing animals.

id_plant_info.Description: Succulent shrub with milky juice; stems green, often zig-zag; leaves alternate, simple, pointed, green or white-edged; flowers red and clustered at the ends of branches; fruit a capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Irritation of the mouth and throat, vomiting and diarrhea when ingested; skin irritation, rash, and blistering and eye irritation upon contact
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: These plump, colored beans can be distinguished from the common lima bean or navy bean by distinct lines radiating from the scar at the center of the inner curved side
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Raw beans (seeds) and roots of ornamental varieties
id_plant_info.Symptoms: These proteins have antinutritional effects, suppressing growth, and may be fatal.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Climbing, evergreen vines; leaves alternate, simple, large, glossy, dark green, and variously shaped; flowers seldom formed as a house plant, crowded on a spadix and surrounded by a spathe.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Intense burning and swelling of the lips, tongue, and throat, difficulty of speaking. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may also occur. Frequent contact with cell sap may cause skin irritation.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals and possibly other toxins.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Chinese lantern, Ground cherry, Jerusalem cherry, strawberry tomato
id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herbs, often much branched and spreading at the top; leaves alternate, simple, smooth margined or irregularly toothed; flowers axillary, nodding, 5-parted, bell- or funnel-shaped, yellowish; fruit a globose yellow, red, purple, or blue-black berry surrounded by a papery sac.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, stomach pain, lowered temperature, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation; may be fatal.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: A large, smooth, branching herb from a large, perennial rootstock, and with green, red, or purple stems; leaves alternate and simple; flowers white, on a long stem, more or less erect; fruit a dark purple berry composed of 5-12 segments fused in a ring, the stem drooping; differs by having shorter, erect fruiting stems
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: All parts, mainly the roots; shoots, leaves, and berries when fresh and in quantity
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning of mouth and throat, salivation, severe stomach irritation, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, spasms, convulsions; can be fatal
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Phytolaccatoxin and related triterpene saponins, an alkaloid (phytolaccin), and histamines
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Fetter-bush, Mountain andromeda, Mountain pieris, mountain fetter-bush
id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub with hairy twigs; leaves alternate and simple, leathery; flowers in terminal, erect clusters, each white, inverted urn-shaped, the short, 5 lobes spreading; fruit a round capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Tingling sensation, salivation, nose and eyes watering, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, weakness, convulsions; may be fatal
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Herbaceous annuals and perennials; leaves alternate, simple or divided, some aromatic; flowers 5-parted, variously colored.

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Tingling sensation, salivation, nose and eyes watering, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, weakness, convulsions; may be fatal
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, vomiting, diarrhea, excitement, headache, fever, coma

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade; flowers usually solitary, 5-parted, white or pinkish; fruit fleshy with a large pit (stone), yellow or reddish

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial or annual herbs; leaves alternate, palmately lobed or divided; flower yellow, thimblelike, often shiny; fruit a head of small, dry achenes.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Ingestion causes burning of the mouth, abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea. Skin redness, burning sensation, and blisters following contact with cell sap.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Protoanemonin, released from the glycoside ranunculin.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Woody, evergreen or deciduous shrubs; leaves alternate, simple, smooth- or toothed-margined; flowers in a terminal cluster, tubular, 5-parted, white to deep pink or yellow; fruit an elongated capsule.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, abdominal pain, loss of energy, depression, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, difficult breathing, progressive paralysis of arms and legs, coma.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Climbing, woody vines or shrub; leaves alternate, pinnately divided with 7-19 leaflets each with a smooth margin; flowers large, pea-like, in elongated, terminal, pendent clusters, white or most often blue or violet; fruit a hairy, flattened pod with a few seeds.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Wisterin, a glycoside, and a toxic resin.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Low, evergreen plants with fern-like, pinnately divided leaves and erect cones; seeds fleshy, orange-yellow or reddish.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: EDIBLE PARTS: Processed flour made from the root is not toxic and is made into bread and spaghetti.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Calla lily, florist's calla, garden calla
id_plant_info.Description: Herbaceous, bulbous perennial; leaves long and strap-like; flowers small, in a spadix surrounded by a white spathe.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Severe burning sensation and swelling of lips, tongue, and throat; stomach pain and diarrhea possible.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals and possibly others.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb; leaves mostly at base, alternate, simple, narrow and grass-like; flowers in large terminal clusters, white or cream, 6-parted, each with 1-2 yellowish glands at the base on the upper side; fruit a capsule.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, burning of mouth and throat, salivation, muscular weakness, vomiting, diarrhea.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Common_Name: American white hellebore, False hellebore, Indian poke, hellebore
id_plant_info.Description: Erect, perennial herb; leaves alternate, broad and strap-like, clasping at the base and with conspicuous parallel veins; flowers greenish yellow, in a large terminal cluster; fruit a capsule
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning of mouth and throat, salivation, headache, stomach pain, vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, sweating, convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb; leaves mostly at base, alternate, simple, narrow and grass-like; flowers in large terminal clusters, white or cream, 6-parted, each with 1-2 yellowish glands at the base on the upper side; fruit a capsule.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Mountain laurel, ivy bush, mountain ivy
id_plant_info.Description: Large, evergreen shrub; leaves alternate and simple; flowers pinkish, in terminal clusters, each saucer-shaped with 5 shallow lobes, the 10 anthers at first stuck in small pockets; fruit a capsule; multiple cultivars available, including dwarf forms ('Minuet' grows to 3 ft.)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, slow pulse, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, tingling of skin, lack of coordination, convulsions, paralysis
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Andromedotoxin, a resinoid; arbutin, a glycoside
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!
